content.webTitle: The Open 2014: Tiger Woods can contend says world No4 Matt Kuchar

fields.headline: The Open 2014: Tiger Woods can contend says world No4 Matt Kuchar
fields.bodyText: The latest assertion that Tiger Woods has a viable chance of winning the Open has arrived from a first-hand witness to the state of the 14-times major winner’s game. Given that Woods played 12 holes at Royal Liverpool in bad weather on Saturday, it was no surprise that he took to the links for a full 18 at midday on Sunday in glorious sunshine. World No4 Matt Kuchar and Gary Woodland were Woods’s partners, with the former insisting afterwards that the recently deposed world No1 can prevail again at Hoylake this week despite a run of eight years since his last Open win. Woods has played only one tournament – he missed the cut at the National Championship at Congressional – since having back surgery in late March. Bookmakers generally have some or all of Rory McIlroy, Adam Scott, Henrik Stenson, Martin Kaymer and Justin Rose priced shorter than Woods to claim the Claret Jug. “I absolutely think he could contend,” Kuchar said. “The Open, the knowledge he has, the skill-set he has? Yes, he could definitely contend.” Woods has played in five Opens from 2007 onwards. He has two top 10 finishes, a tie for 23rd, a share of 12th and a missed cut during that spell. Woods’s last major victory came at the 2008 US Open. “He was impressive out there,” Kuchar said. “I thought he was crazy to come back as early as he did [after surgery] but he said he thought it was the right thing to do, to test it and see how fit he is. He said he is recovering well, that after playing he gets up the next day and feels good. “We had a little match going and on the last hole he duly stuffed one in there close from 160 yards to beat me. So that was a bit of a bummer but totally like the Tiger we’re used to seeing.” Another familiar sight was that of Woods opting not to use a single driver throughout Sunday’s practice round. When he won here on Merseyside in 2006, he famously used his driver only once in 72 competition holes. The venue is not as fast-running as eight years ago but accuracy, rather than length, remains the necessary component. For his part, Woods is showing no obvious signs of physical limitation at all when on the course. “I’ve got my speed back, which is nice,” he said. “I’m starting to hit the ball out there again. I’m only going to get stronger. As the weeks go on, I’m getting strong and faster.” When asked to describe his level of confidence, Woods claimed it is growing. A counter view has arrived from Nick Faldo. The three-times Open champion believes Woods “has the cards stacked against him this week”. Faldo also finds it curious that Woods did not prepare for this, the 143rd Open, by adding an extra event such as the Scottish Open to his schedule. “He has played two rounds and thinks he’s ready,” said Faldo of Woods. “He left Congressional saying he knew what to work on, so we’ll see. He looked rusty, and you have got to be rusty after that sort of break. You’ve got to get out there and play. He sounds confused when he says he needs reps and then doesn’t play.” Glancing back to 2006, Faldo said: “The course has got to play longer, because that was burnt. As you know he hit 2-irons from the tee bar one, and then he was going in with 4-irons and things like that. I think they calculated he was playing an 8,500 yards course playing it that way. Seriously. “So that was Tiger at his optimum. That was him in a Tiger zen.”
